questions.question: What key change turns a classifier into a fully convolutional network (FCN) for dense prediction?
options: Replacing fully connected layers with convolutions (e.g., 1×1 convs) on the feature map.

questions.question: Why can an FCN accept arbitrary input image sizes?
options: It always resizes inputs to a fixed crop.
It removes the fixed-size FC layers and uses only convolutions, which operate on grids of any size.

questions.question: In segmentation, a 1×1 convolution on a feature map acts as:
options: A per-pixel classifier mapping channels → class logits.

questions.question: What is the main limitation of FCN-32s compared to FCN-16s/8s?
options: It produces blurrier boundaries because it upsamples from very coarse (stride-32) features.

questions.question: Why do skip connections (FCN-16s/8s) help?
options: They reduce the number of parameters.
They remove the need for upsampling.
They fuse shallow, high-resolution cues ("where") with deep, semantic cues ("what").

questions.question: In your slides, which variant typically gives sharpest boundaries?
Before adding two tensors from different stages (e.g., upsampled conv5 with pool4 scores), you must:
options: Match their spatial sizes (H × W), e.g., with bilinear F.interpolate.
Convert them to probabilities with sigmoid.
